sectionName: GMAT Verbal Practice - Mixed RC and CR
testDescription: This section tests reading comprehension and critical reasoning skills through challenging passages and logical reasoning problems.

passages.title: Vietnam's Economic Transformation
passages.content:
IT IS A contrarian argument from an improbable contrarian. Vietnam's economy may be the envy of South-East Asia, having averaged 6% annual growth over the past 15 years, but it is in urgent need of radical reform. So, at any rate, asserts To Lam, who spent eight years running Vietnam's ruthless security services before becoming general secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party last year. He is busy sacking civil servants and amending economic laws in pursuit of a "revolution" to "liberate all productive forces". "Time does not wait for us," he warned his comrades soon after taking charge.

Vietnam's economy has come a long way since the Vietnam war ended 50 years ago, leaving an already poor country in ruins. At first the victorious communist regime tried to "liquidate" the private sector. Shortages, rationing and hunger followed. In the 1980s the Soviet Union's economic troubles meant less aid for Vietnam, exacerbating the malaise. Annual inflation reached 454% and half of Vietnamese were living in poverty. The death of one of Mr Lam's predecessors in 1986 paved the way for a new general secretary to legalise private enterprise and embrace market forces.

Doi moi or "renovation" has been an astonishing success. Over the past 40 years GDP per person has increased 18-fold and poverty has plummeted. Foreign investors, attracted by Vietnam's cheap labour, political stability (it is a single-party, authoritarian state), proximity to Asian suppliers and generous incentives for manufacturing, have built lots of factories assembling consumer goods for export. A trade deal with America, accession to the World Trade Organisation and, more recently, multinationals' desire to diversify away from China have provided further reasons to invest.

Yet the forces that have propelled Vietnam's boom are slowing or reversing. The pool of cheap workers is dwindling and wages are rising. Instead of largely free trade with America, Donald Trump is threatening tariffs of 46%. It is getting harder to maintain good relations with both America and China, Vietnam's second-biggest trading partner. And there has been relatively little spillover from the foreign-owned factories to the rest of the economy. Vietnam risks becoming stuck as an assembly hub, adding little value to components manufactured elsewhere. Shifting onto a more promising developmental path will not be easyâ€”and Mr Lam is staking his tenure on it.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of the passage?

options.A: To analyze the historical factors that led to Vietnam's economic transformation since the 1980s
options.B: To explain why Vietnam needs economic reform despite its impressive recent growth performance
options.C: To compare Vietnam's development strategy with other successful Southeast Asian economies
options.D: To describe the dominant role of foreign investment in Vietnam's manufacturing sector
options.E: To evaluate To Lam's leadership credentials and policy proposals for economic reform

questions.questionText: According to the passage, which of the following best describes Vietnam's most pressing economic challenge?

options.A: Insufficient foreign direct investment to sustain current levels of economic growth
options.B: Political instability that undermines long-term investor confidence in the country
options.C: The risk of being caught between low-wage assembly work and high-tech innovation
options.D: Declining export volumes due to increasing global trade tensions and protectionism
options.E: A critical shortage of agricultural workers needed to maintain food security

questions.questionText: The author's attitude toward Vietnam's economic transformation can best be described as:

options.A: Unqualified admiration for the country's remarkable developmental achievements
options.B: Deep skepticism about the long-term sustainability of foreign investment-driven growth
options.C: Confident optimism about To Lam's ability to successfully implement necessary reforms
options.D: Appreciative of past success while expressing concern about significant future challenges
options.E: Sharply critical of the government's historical failure to develop competitive local industries

questions.questionText: Company X is considering whether to open a new manufacturing facility in Southeast Asia. The company's executives argue that rising labor costs in their current location make expansion necessary for maintaining profitability. Which of the following, if true, would most weaken this argument?

options.A: Labor costs in Southeast Asia are currently 30% lower than in the company's current location
options.B: The company's main competitors have recently opened facilities in Southeast Asia
options.C: Automation technology could reduce labor requirements by 40% at the current facility
options.D: Transportation costs from Southeast Asia would add 15% to total production expenses
options.E: The company's current facility is operating at only 60% capacity

questions.questionText: Economist: "Countries that invest heavily in renewable energy infrastructure will have significant economic advantages in the coming decades. Green energy costs are falling rapidly, and carbon pricing mechanisms will make fossil fuels increasingly expensive." Which of the following assumptions is necessary for this argument?

options.A: Renewable energy technology will continue to improve at its current rate
options.B: All countries will eventually implement carbon pricing mechanisms
options.C: The economic advantages will outweigh the initial infrastructure investment costs
options.D: Fossil fuel prices will remain volatile in the coming decades
options.E: International cooperation on climate policy will increase significantly

questions.questionText: A recent study found that employees who work remotely are 20% more productive than those who work in traditional offices. However, remote workers also report feeling less connected to their colleagues and company culture. Which of the following best resolves this apparent contradiction?

options.A: Productivity and workplace satisfaction are independent factors that don't necessarily correlate
options.B: The study measured short-term productivity but long-term effects may be different
options.C: Remote workers compensate for social isolation by focusing more intensely on their tasks
options.D: Traditional office environments create distractions that reduce individual productivity
options.E: The benefits of remote work vary significantly across different types of job roles
